 'Carboxysomes' are bacterial microcompartments that contain enzymes involved in
 carbon fixation. Carboxysomes are made of polyhedral protein shells
 about 80 to 140 nanometres in diameter. These compartments are thought to
 concentrate carbon dioxide to overcome the inefficiency of RuBisCO - the
 predominant enzyme in carbon fixation and the rate limiting enzyme in the
 Calvin cycle. These organelles are found in all cyanobacteria and many
 chemotrophic bacteria that fix carbon dioxide.

Carboxysomes are an example of a wider group of protein micro-compartments that
have dissimilar functions, but similar structures, based on homology of the two
shell protein families.
